Variation based upon race/ethnicity is noticable but not drastic. Group E (highest) averages about 10 points higher than group A (lowest).

Regardless, this may potentially be used to inform quality of education based on community. A further study comparing more homogenized school districts vs more divers districts may be warranted to see the outcome of diversity on education and test performance.

This could also possibly inform funding or systemic issues within the educational system, depending on what further data can be obtained.

On initial inspection this appears to show that students on a free/reduced lunch program scored lower on average than students on standard lunch, across the board.

while this may be significant, the smaller sample size of free/reduced lunch does cast doubt. Repeated studies may be necessary to determine actual correlation.

If we decide that there is correlation here and that lunch status informs household income status, this should be cause for concern. Without quality education it can be hard for citizens to rise above poor financial situations. The largest difference appears to be in math scores which is even greater cause for concern. Math skills directly impact things like the ability properly manage personal accounting matters.
